conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions Committee—I'm Student_C and I’m applying because School_C is my first-choice school. If admitted, I will accept and commit to enrolling. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_C, and all schools share the same priority order where I rank below Student_A and Student_B. To maximize my chance at the best possible match, I should apply immediately to my first choice rather than risk losing the single seat to higher-priority applicants who may also target it. I will send a clear, committed application emphasizing School_C is my first choice.

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_C. Please confirm your commitment and we look forward to welcoming you.
conversation.thought: Student_C is applying and ranks School_C as their first choice, which makes the match likely to be stable. However, on School_C’s true priority list, Student_C is ranked 3rd behind Student_A and Student_B. Given we have quota 1 and only Student_C has applied this round, we must weigh holding out for higher-priority students vs securing a committed first-choice applicant now. Student_A prefers School_B then School_A then School_C; Student_B prefers School_A then School_C; both may not apply to School_C in round 1 and could be captured by School_A/School_B quickly. Accepting Student_C now ensures we fill the seat with a student on our list and avoid ending unmatched; the opportunity cost of waiting is high because higher-ranked students have stronger alternatives and may never reach us. Therefore accept.

conversation.message: Hello School_E Admissions Committee—I'm Student_E. School_E is my first-choice school, and if admitted I will enroll. I’m excited about the opportunity to join your community and contribute actively to classes and school activities. Thank you for considering my application.

Accepting Student_E now would lock in my lowest-ranked option and prevent upgrading. Therefore, reject.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

Thank you again for reviewing my application. I understand the decision, but School_E remains my first choice. If there is any possibility of reconsideration (e.g., a waitlist) or if additional information could help (updated grades, recommendations, or a short statement of fit), I would be grateful for the chance to provide it. 

Could you please let me know whether your decision is final for this cycle, or whether there is any remaining pathway for admission?

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: School_E is my top choice but already rejected me, so a second immediate APPLY is unlikely to succeed. With only School_D and School_E remaining, and School_D being last on my true list, the best move is to TALK to School_E to see if there is any reconsideration/waitlist path or missing information I can provide. If School_E is definitively closed, I can pivot to applying to School_D next round rather than risk going unmatched.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful follow-up and for your continued interest in School_E.

At this time, our single available seat has been filled, so we’re not able to reconsider your application for admission this cycle. If a seat were to open later, we would review next-step options at that time, but we cannot offer a waitlist pathway or request additional materials right now.

We appreciate the time you’ve put into the process and wish you the very best with your remaining choices.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: We have quota 0 and are already matched with Student_D. Student_E is lowest on our true priority list and was previously rejected. Student_E is only talking, asking about reconsideration/waitlist. Given capacity is full, we should maintain current match and communicate decision is final unless a seat opens; we can offer a waitlist-style note but no acceptance now.

conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_E. I understand your seat is still available, and I would like to formally apply. While my earlier choices were different, I have strong respect for School_D’s community and academics, and I would be grateful for the opportunity to join.

If admitted, I will enroll and commit fully to contributing in class and to school activities.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_D remains unmatched. School_D is on my true preference list (though ranked last), and I prefer matching with it over being unmatched. Since seats are scarce and this is the remaining available option, I should apply now and clearly commit to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message: Student_E, thank you for your application and for your interest in School_D. After reviewing our current priorities and the fact that we have only one seat available, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your time and wish you the best in the rest of your admissions process.

Student_E is applying again; accepting now would fill the only seat with the lowest-priority option and eliminate any chance to match with A/B/C if they approach later. With rounds remaining and no requirement to fill the seat, it is optimal to reject Student_E and continue waiting for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions Committee,

Thank you again for considering my earlier application. I understand you have a single seat and must follow your priority order.

I wanted to ask whether your seat is still currently unfilled, and if there is any possibility of reconsideration if higher-priority applicants have now matched elsewhere. If you are able to admit me at any point, I can confirm immediately that I will enroll.

If reconsideration is not possible, could you let me know whether there is any remaining step in your process (e.g., a final check-in or timeline) so I can plan accordingly?

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_D remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though lowest). I was already rejected on a prior [APPLY], so a direct re-application is unlikely to change the outcome. A [TALK] message can check whether circumstances have changed (seat still open, reconsideration possible if higher-priority students matched elsewhere) and express willingness to enroll immediately if admitted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for following up. At this time, our seat is still not committed, but we are continuing to hold it while we assess the market and potential movement from higher-priority applicants.

I’m not able to reconsider an offer to you right now. If higher-priority applicants match elsewhere and our seat remains available, we may be able to revisit later rounds. If that happens, the appropriate next step would be for you to send a fresh [APPLY] message in a later round so we can make a formal decision at that time.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: As School_D, my true priority list ranks Student_E last. I still have 1 seat, but accepting Student_E now could block a higher-priority student (A/B/C) from matching with me later if they become unmatched or decide to apply down their list. Student_E is only [TALK] this round, so no accept/reject decision is required. Best strategy is to keep the seat open, be transparent that no offer is available now, and invite Student_E to check back and/or apply again later if the seat remains after higher-priority candidates resolve elsewhere.

conversation.message:

If the market shifts and our seat remains uncommitted later, you are welcome to submit another fresh [APPLY] in a subsequent round for reconsideration.

School_D Admissions

In this market, Student_D already applied and was rejected; A/B/C have higher preferences for other schools and may not reach us, but it is still possible they do if rejected elsewhere. Since our objective is to match as high as possible on our priority list, we should continue holding the seat rather than accept the lowest-priority student this early. Therefore, reject Student_E again while leaving the door open to re-apply in later rounds if the market clears.
